utterances: People realize at such a young age what he accomplished - got an education, did a tremendous job.
Wasn't the nicest person in the world but I don't think he could have accomplished what he did if he was.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
We came out today just to show the children of the importance of it being an industry here in the city of Detroit, especially with everything that's going on with the bankruptcy and things like that.
So, I just wanted them to see something good for a change.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
I'm surprised that it's already been 150 years.
I'm just thinking what it will be like when it's his 200th.
I'll be gone but I think he'll be driving something that's very, very sustainable.
It'll be the fuels and the drive trains and that kind of thing of the cars that'll be different 50 years ago.
There'll be just as fast, just as cool and just as fun to drive.
But a lot more economical.
We heard Sibelly Cedric(ph), Bill Ford, Jr., Rose Rondy(ph), Lisa Smith, Jack Bennett and his mother Katie Bennett reminiscing about Henry Ford on the occasion of his 150th birthday.
You're listening to NPR News.
And now we have a little behind the scenes scene for you from last nights State of the Union Address.
There were hundreds of journalists waiting in the Capitol Statuary Hall and NPR's Andrea Seabrook said they almost had a giant collective heart attack.
Light glared, TV cameras were ready to roll and radio reporters stood by to go live when the power went out.
See none of this fancy technology works without juice.
So this intrepid reporter prepared for a very different story.
(Soundbite of Andrea Seabroook):
I'm standing in Statuary Hall and lawmakers are dumping into this big great hall full of statues after the president's speech.
I assume that Jim Webb is on the air now or in just a couple of minutes - and the lights have come back on.
And there are jubilant television producers across the room.
And producers there were.
Dozens of them.
And cameramen, correspondents, runners, and gophers, even at the BBC?
Peers Whisby(ph) is a producer for the British network.
Well and there are more BBC producers and correspondents here than probably any other American network I think.
We go nuts on this sort of thing.
What does this look like to you?
I mean you've covered the British government right?
Yeah.
I mean.
Yeah.
Well to be honest, American politics is so much razzamatazz than the rest I think.
It's a personality, it's a sense of fun, of excitement and people really enjoy covering it.
People love working in politics too.
Florida congressman Adam Putnam is the chairman of the house republican conference.
I guess for political junkies it's kind of like Oscar night.
You know they bring in the diplomatic corp, then the bring in the cabinet, and then they bring in the Supreme Court, and the Joint Chiefs.
Pretty much all politicians are, by nature, political junkies.
As Putnam demonstrates.
The parlor game on the floor is always to figure out who the special guest that year is going to be.
Right, yeah, and who was it this year?
You know the hero of the New York subway was by far the most popular.
And that guy is a great American hero and then his reaction to being called out by the president was captured (unintelligible) heart.
What did he do?
(unintelligible).
You know he's giving the old Sammy Sosa, beat the chest, kiss two fingers and give it up for the crowd.
That guy who leapt in front of the speeding subway to save a stranger was just one of the celebs in the gallery.
There was basketball great Dekembe Mutombo and actor Michael J.
Fox.
He was the guest of another strong advocate of stem cell research, Rhode Island Democrat Jim Langeman.
I told him I'm a big fan of his acting, I loved him on ""Family Ties,"" of course we all loved him in ""Back to the Future"" he's such a talented actor.
But this fight with stem cell research he said, is one of the highlights of his, of his life and when he really is making a difference for millions of people.
And in just an amazing way, I, I give him such great credit.
He's a special person.
See, even elected officials can be star struck.
And you should have seen the fawning over Barack Obama.
But after all the excitement and pageantry and spin down, just about every journalist was most thankful for one thing, that the power came back on.
Andrea Seabrook, NPR News, the Capitol.
It's DAY TO DAY.
I'm Noah Adams.
And I'm Madeleine Brand.
On Monday, New Year's Day, some 38 million people are expected to watch the Annual Rose Parade on television.
In Pasadena, thousands of spectators will line the parade route, hoping to catch a glimpse of the 89th Rose Queen and her Royal Court.
And I'm Alex Chadwick in San Francisco, where across the bay in Sausalito a new bicycle race begins on Monday.

It's the opening of what sponsors call the Tour of California, and which they say they intend to eventually raise to a level where it will rival one of the biggest sporting events in the world, the Tour de France.
Other American organizers have tried this before and failed.
But there's a lot of money behind this effort.
John Bradley is an editor at Outside magazine, a biker and a race fan.
And we've reached him at his office in Santa Fe, New Mexico.
John Bradley, welcome to the program.
And more about this race.
Where does it begin?
Where does it end?
It starts in the San Francisco Bay Area and finishes up in the Los Angeles area.
It kind of hugs the coastline the whole way for about 750 miles over eight days.
And is it going to be like that Tour de France, do you know, where they're riding mountains and flats, and all over the place?
I mean, it's quite challenging.
It's very challenging.
It's actually more mountains than flats.
There's only stage in the whole thing that I would really call a flat stage.
Otherwise it's going to be pretty grueling, especially for this early in the season.
It's really going to be testing the riders.
I did wonder about the timing for the organizers here.
I mean, the Olympics are on right now.
Sports fans' attention is diverted there.
And well, it's winter.
In Northern California, there was a freeze and frost warning last night.
They could run into ice.
Why now?
You know, I think, less than the ice, it's just going to be the winds and the waves coming in off the Pacific.
But I think the big thing is that the cycling season is just getting started now.
And this is, you know, one hole in the international calendar where there aren't really any races that are competing against this one.
So who is behind this?
It was started by a group of people who, you know, have wanted to establish a world-class race in the United States.
And one of the problems with doing that is that, you know, it's not necessarily a big money-generating sport in this country, at least not yet.
So what's happened with this is that Phil Anschutz, who owns Qwest Communications, has kind of bankrolled this himself and has guaranteed to keep the race going even if sponsorship drops out.
So the race has much better financial footing than anything else that's been started in the U.S.
to this point.
But you know, with Lance Armstrong retired now, do Americans still care enough about bike racing, so that this could actually get going and rival the Tour de France?
You know, rivaling the Tour de France, I think, was great P.R.
language, but I don't think that anybody expects that to happened.
I mean, cycling-crazy nations like Italy and Spain could never do anything to rival the Tour de France.
So I don't think that that's going to happen.
Will people pay attention?
I hope so.
You know, Lance is part of a kind of a golden generation of cyclists in the U.S.
There's still a lot of guys from his generation who are out there riding, and definitely making dents in Europe.
And this, I think, is a great chance for them to kind of showcase their skills in the U.S.
Is this going to be on TV?
I think that's the way you tell whether a sporting event has really arrived in the United States, isn't it?
Is someone going to be broadcasting this so race fans can actually follow it?
Yeah.
Every night, ESPN 2 is going to be broadcasting highlights of the race.
Everything is in line for this to be a success, as long as the fans are there.
And if you look at, you know, the cities that this is passing through, they've got great viewing points all along the route.
So they've definitely made it a very viewer friendly event, as well.
How about the teams that are participating.
Is this drawing the world's really great riders?
Absolutely.
It's a world-class field, as good as you'd find at any race in Europe.
John Bradley is an editor at Outside magazine, speaking with us from his office in Santa Fe, New Mexico, about the Tour de California.
Well, that's the Tour of California.
It begins on Monday.
John Bradley, thank you.
Thank you.
